articles.headline: State Farm in Talks to Settle Gulf Claims
articles.snippet: The nation’s biggest home insurer is close to settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes hit by Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: The nation’s biggest home insurer is close to settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes hit by Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

articles.headline: California Plan for Health Care Would Cover All
articles.snippet: Under a plan by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, California would become the largest state to attempt to provide near universal health coverage.
articles.abstract: Under a plan by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, California would become the largest state to attempt to provide near universal health coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Monday proposed extending health care coverage to all of California’s 36 million residents as part of a sweeping package of changes to the state’s huge, troubled health care system.

articles.headline: Hussein’s Voice Speaks in Court in Praise of Chemical Atrocities
articles.snippet: In recordings played in court, Saddam Hussein was heard justifying the use of chemical weapons against the Iraqi Kurds.
articles.abstract: In recordings played in court, Saddam Hussein was heard justifying the use of chemical weapons against the Iraqi Kurds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 8 — The courtroom he dominated for 15 months seemed much smaller on Monday without him there to mock the judges and assert his menacing place in history.

articles.headline: It’s Detroit, but Accents Are Foreign
articles.snippet: The auto show in Detroit is living up to its global name with new players from China and a new pecking order in the U.S. market.
articles.abstract: The auto show in Detroit is living up to its global name with new players from China and a new pecking order in the U.S. market.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Jan. 8 — The auto show in Detroit has always been something of a living time capsule. The cars may change, but the auto companies, their place in the universe, and the faces here always seemed to remain the same.

articles.headline: Paying in Pollution for Energy Hunger
articles.snippet: India and China have explored alternatives, but too often the diesel generator is the favorite way to provide energy.
articles.abstract: India and China have explored alternatives, but too often the diesel generator is the favorite way to provide energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAHARBARI, India — A toxic purple haze of diesel exhaust hangs over the rice and jute fields here in northeastern India, and bird songs are frequently drowned out by the chug-a-chug-a-chug of diesel generators.

articles.headline: Gap Is Said to Explore Selling Itself
articles.snippet: Gap is said to be exploring strategies ranging from the sale of its 3,000 stores to spinning off a single division, like Banana Republic.
articles.abstract: Gap is said to be exploring strategies ranging from the sale of its 3,000 stores to spinning off a single division, like Banana Republic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gap, the casual clothing chain that turned staples like T-shirts into must-have fashions and spawned scores of imitators that nibbled away at its business, is exploring a sale of the company, people briefed on the matter said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Mortgage Applications Up as Home Buyers See a Break in Rates
articles.snippet: Low mortgage interest rates are buoying the housing market even as experts are debating whether the market has hit bottom.
articles.abstract: Low mortgage interest rates are buoying the housing market even as experts are debating whether the market has hit bottom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Low mortgage interest rates are buoying the housing market even as experts are debating whether the market has hit bottom.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Christine Haughney
